match.title: 38th Match, Pool A
match.statusText: England won by 9 wickets (with 41 balls remaining) (D/L method)
match.hoursInfo: 14.30 start, First Session 14.30-18.00, Interval 18.00-18.45, Second Session 18.45-22.15

dismissalText.commentary: Shafiqullah c Bopara b Tredwell 30 (64b 1x4 0x6 73m) SR: 46.87

dismissalComment.html: Bopara is doing everything today. Shafiq tries the big sweep, gets a big top edge that flies around deep square leg. Bopara from fine leg and Jordan from deep midwicket converge, but nobody seems to have called for this. Jordan lets it go at the last moment, and Bopara takes it with a late dive to his left. Inches off the ground

dismissalText.commentary: Nasir Jamal c †Buttler b Bopara 17 (52b 2x4 0x6 75m) SR: 32.69

dismissalComment.html: and a wicket immediately after the break. Just a gentle length ball outside off. Maybe it holds its line a touch but mostly a straight delivery. Jamal gets forward but not quite close to it. he also opens the face. Easy catch for Buttler

and there he gets the wicket. Keeps pitching it up, just outside off, gets the ball to hold its line. It is on a length. Not quite a half-volley so the half-forward movement doesn't cover the movement. The regulation outside edge settles with Buttler

another wicket falls. Jordan keeps bowling at a length outside off. Sami drives hard at it. The ball holds its line, takes a thick edge square on the off side. Morgan takes a low catch diving forward at point

and a wicket immediately after the break. Just a gentle length ball outside off. Maybe it holds its line a touch but mostly a straight delivery. Jamal gets forward but not quite close to it. he also opens the face. Easy catch for Buttler
soft dismissal. Nabi has taken it upon himself to provide some impetus to this innings. He has been taking risks in order to do so. Gets a short ball, pulls it hard, but straight down mid-on's throat

dismissalText.commentary: Nawroz Mangal c Root b Anderson 4 (28b 0x4 0x6 25m) SR: 14.28

dismissalComment.html: that's a nothing shot. This is short of a length, wide, moving away, Mangal just hangs his bat out horizontally. The edge is taken, and Root takes it overhead at first slip

dismissalText.commentary: Javed Ahmadi c Root b Broad 7 (15b 0x4 0x6 31m) SR: 46.66

dismissalComment.html: Root in business again. A perfect length ball for a slightly loose batsman. Ahmadi drives at it away from the body, the ball moves away a touch, the edge is taken, and Root takes a simple catch at first slip

dismissalText.commentary: Afsar Zazai c †Buttler b Jordan 6 (14b 0x4 0x6 21m) SR: 42.85

dismissalComment.html: and there he gets the wicket. Keeps pitching it up, just outside off, gets the ball to hold its line. It is on a length. Not quite a half-volley so the half-forward movement doesn't cover the movement. The regulation outside edge settles with Buttler

dismissalText.commentary: Samiullah Shinwari c Morgan b Jordan 7 (11b 1x4 0x6 16m) SR: 63.63

dismissalComment.html: another wicket falls. Jordan keeps bowling at a length outside off. Sami drives hard at it. The ball holds its line, takes a thick edge square on the off side. Morgan takes a low catch diving forward at point

dismissalText.commentary: Nasir Jamal c †Buttler b Bopara 17 (52b 2x4 0x6 75m) SR: 32.69

dismissalComment.html: and a wicket immediately after the break. Just a gentle length ball outside off. Maybe it holds its line a touch but mostly a straight delivery. Jamal gets forward but not quite close to it. he also opens the face. Easy catch for Buttler

dismissalText.commentary: Mohammad Nabi c Tredwell b Bopara 16 (17b 1x4 1x6 19m) SR: 94.11

dismissalComment.html: soft dismissal. Nabi has taken it upon himself to provide some impetus to this innings. He has been taking risks in order to do so. Gets a short ball, pulls it hard, but straight down mid-on's throat

dismissalText.commentary: Shafiqullah c Bopara b Tredwell 30 (64b 1x4 0x6 73m) SR: 46.87

dismissalComment.html: Bopara is doing everything today. Shafiq tries the big sweep, gets a big top edge that flies around deep square leg. Bopara from fine leg and Jordan from deep midwicket converge, but nobody seems to have called for this. Jordan lets it go at the last moment, and Bopara takes it with a late dive to his left. Inches off the ground

dismissalText.commentary: Ian Bell not out 52 (56b 6x4 0x6 81m) SR: 92.85
Alex Hales c †Afsar Zazai b Hamid Hassan 37 (33b 3x4 2x6 58m) SR: 112.12

dismissalComment.html: and Hassan gets a wicket on his final night of the World Cup. Something to cheer about at least. On a length, just outside off, seams away a touch. Hales is looking to defend, playing the angle, and ends up edging this through to the keeper

and Hassan gets a wicket on his final night of the World Cup. Something to cheer about at least. On a length, just outside off, seams away a touch. Hales is looking to defend, playing the angle, and ends up edging this through to the keeper

dismissalText.commentary: Alex Hales c †Afsar Zazai b Hamid Hassan 37 (33b 3x4 2x6 58m) SR: 112.12

dismissalComment.html: and Hassan gets a wicket on his final night of the World Cup. Something to cheer about at least. On a length, just outside off, seams away a touch. Hales is looking to defend, playing the angle, and ends up edging this through to the keeper

commentTextItems.html: down the wicket to bunt this to midwicket for a single that ends the match

commentPostTextItems.html: With a hint of sadness we must bid farewell to the mighty Afghans. You played with passion, you gave it your all. Those expressive faces, the lack of inhibition when you celebrated and when you admonished your team-mates will be missed. You might have lost today but you got stuck at the wrong end of the toss on a miserably rainy day. Hope to see you play more international cricket some time soon

England were efficient on their final day of the World Cup, but they will have to look back at their attitude towards the modern limited-overs game, their planning, and their personnel, both in the leadership and among the players. Thanks for joining us. Goodbye

"A tough toss to lose in those conditions," says Mohammad Nabi. "Suitable for their bowlers. Then the rain intervals. Difficult to adjust. They bowled brilliantly, in the right areas, swinging it both ways. We have leant a lot from this tournament. How Full Members play, how they build pressure. The Scotland win was a good memory for the whole team."

"A lot to learn from this tournament," says Eoin Morgan "We have got a good squad of players who are here. It is important to realise we haven't clicked this tournament. It has been challenging, I have learnt a lot about myself and about the players. I have learnt a lot from the coach Peter Moores. I have known him better. I have enjoyed the experience. Yes it [captaincy] is something I will like to do. We will sit down over a couple of weeks and see where things have gone wrong and how we can fix them.""

"Nice to pick this award," says Chris Jordan, the Man of the Match. "Helpful conditions. A bit of nibble, a bit of swing. Just tried to put it in the right areas. Shame we couldn't go further but enjoyed being part of the England team. Need to improve my consistency, grouping of balls, and my batting at the back end of our innings."

commentPreTextItems.html: DJ: "Mybe England misread the rules, and think that if they chase down in less than 20 overs it's a no-result"

commentTextItems.html: looks to pull this from outside off, ends up playing it to mid-off
looks to cut, the ball is not wide enough, gets an edge fine of third man for a couple

commentPreTextItems.html: David Glick: "And we wonder why the England setup is so fatally flawed? Any other team would have sent in their "finisher" and get changed and home on the plane. Having been an avid England fan for 40 years, I find myself in envy of Bangladesh!! "

commentTextItems.html: moves back and across and defends. A good Ashes audition going on
short of a length, angling in, he has defended off the back foot
on a length, shaping away, Bell plays with cement feet, gets an inside edge to long leg
short of a length, outside off, Bell cuts. Beaten. Not short enough for the cut

commentPreTextItems.html: James: "Roger, i agree. I'm English, and I was half hoping for an Afgan vicotry, so England couldn't take a single crumb of comfort from this shambles."

commentTextItems.html: short of a length, angling in, he gets behind it in defence

commentPreTextItems.html: shaun: "What's in it for Taylor here? He can be not out 10 or so which means nothing, or he can get out which is dangerous stuff for his career."

commentTextItems.html: short of a length, angling in, Bell dabs this down to third man to get to another fifty. Now time for him to slow down as he usually does in ODI innings

commentPreTextItems.html: Mani: "I wish England could have qualified for the QF to make India's life easier!"

commentTextItems.html: short of a length, wide, Bell looks to cut, top-edges it over slip

commentPreTextItems.html: Ghaznavid: "10 needed off 54 with only 9 wickets in hand. This is such a pressure situation - one can understand why England is being so cautious. They really can't afford to lose 9 wickets here..."

commentTextItems.html: short of a length, rising again, hits the shoulder of the bat, but this time they take a single to point
shorter this time, Taylor goes deep in the crease to try to pull, and is beaten by the lack of bounce this time

commentPreTextItems.html: "This move to prod along when they could have finished the game off in style is a prime reason why not many neutral fans like England," says Roger
Meanwhile, Shapoor Zadran comes back. Round the wicket

commentTextItems.html: short of a length, angling in, chest high, Taylor is off his feet as he defends
full, angling in, pushed straight of mid-on for a single
plays the pull but Hassan is too quick, and he mis-times it to square leg
slower ball gone wrong, it is a wide down the leg side
short of a length, outside off, off his feet to punch this to point
angling too far into the pads, concedes a leg-bye

commentPreTextItems.html: What if it rains at the end of the 19th over with the score at 95? England will then rue sending Taylor up

commentTextItems.html: length ball, angling in, pushed wide of mid-on for one
short of a length, quick, just outside off, Taylor is off his feet as he defends

stories.title: England underwhelm one last time
stories.subTitle: Afghanistan vs England, World Cup 2015, Group A, Sydney

stories.summary: The flaws were still visible in England's win over Afghanistan but to blame the coach and the players does not go far enough

stories.title: Chris Jordan helps England pip Afghanistan
stories.subTitle: Afghanistan v England, World Cup 2015, Group A, Sydney
stories.summary: Chris Jordan's two wickets helped England beat Afghanistan by a nine-wicket margin in their last match of World Cup 2015 match played in Sydney on Friday.

image.caption: Chris Jordan bowls
image.longCaption: Chris Jordan bowls, England v Bangladesh, World Cup 2015, Group A, Adelaide, March 9, 2015

stories.title: Afghanistan's fortunes fade
stories.seoTitle: England vs Afghanistan, 2015 World Cup - Afghanistan's fortunes fade
stories.summary: After a strong start to the World Cup, Afghanistan lost steam in the closing matches, and will be especially disappointed that they couldn't push a dispirited England harder

image.caption: Hamid Hassan had Alex Hales nicking behind for 37
image.longCaption: Hamid Hassan had Alex Hales nicking behind for 37, Afghanistan v England, World Cup 2015, Group A, Sydney, March 13, 2015

stories.title: A very English farewell
stories.subTitle: Afghanistan v England, World Cup 2015, Group A, Sydney
stories.summary: On a suitably hangdog English day, more downcast than overcast, and a match ravaged by rain, an Ian Bell fifty led England to victory with nine wickets to spare

image.caption: Rain played hide and seek, keeping the ground staff busy
image.longCaption: Rain played hide and seek, keeping the ground staff busy, Afghanistan v England, World Cup 2015, Group A, Sydney, March 13, 2015

stories.title: Home-bound England fear one last shock
stories.subTitle: Afghanistan v England, World Cup 2015, Group A, Sydney
stories.seoTitle: Home-bound England fear one last shock
stories.summary: Having been dumped from the World Cup by Bangladesh, England will be petrified of finishing their tournament with another loss to a lower-ranked team. Afghanistan, meanwhile, will look to make the most of their last chance in the game's shop window

image.caption: Alex Hales scored 31 before he was dismissed by Shahid Afridi
image.longCaption: Alex Hales scored 31 before he was dismissed by Shahid Afridi, England v Pakistan, World Cup warm-up, Sydney, February 11, 2015

stories.title: 'Players have let Peter Moores down' - Moles
stories.subTitle: Afg v Eng, Group A, Sydney
stories.seoTitle: 'Players have let Peter Moores down' - Andy Moles
stories.summary: Andy Moles, the Afghanistan coach, has expressed his sympathy for Peter Moores, suggesting England's players "let him down" during the World Cup campaign

image.caption: Afghanistan coach Andy Moles talks to Dawlat Zadran
image.longCaption: Afghanistan coach Andy Moles talks to Dawlat Zadran, Western Australia XI v Afghanistan, Perth, September 22, 2014

stories.title: England stare down yet another fresh start
stories.subTitle: Afg v Eng, Group A, Sydney
stories.seoTitle: England stare down yet another fresh start
stories.summary: As England head towards another new era following their humiliating exit at the World Cup, their assistant coach Paul Farbrace has signaled the need for new recruits, calling for county cricketers to fight for their places in the team

image.caption: Down and out: James Anderson misses a yorker from Rubel Hossain
image.longCaption: Down and out: James Anderson misses a yorker from Rubel Hossain, England v Bangladesh, World Cup 2015, Group A, Adelaide, March 9, 2015

stories.title: 'We'll do whatever you want' - Moles
stories.subTitle: Afg v Eng, Group A, Sydney
stories.summary: While conceding that it was impossible to expect the game's financial giants to schedule additional series against Associates, Afghanistan's coach Andy Moles suggested that his team be used as a warm-up option for encounters against Pakistan in particular

image.caption: Hamid Hassan celebrates after beating Scotland
image.longCaption: Hamid Hassan celebrates as Shapoor Zadran is down on his knees after winning,  Afghanistan v Scotland, World Cup 2015, Group A, Dunedin, February 26, 2015

image.longCaption: Peter Moores and Paul Farbrace, part of England's under-pressure coaching staff, Sydney, March 12, 2015

stories.title: Chris Jordan helps England pip Afghanistan
stories.subTitle: Afghanistan v England, World Cup 2015, Group A, Sydney
stories.summary: Chris Jordan's two wickets helped England beat Afghanistan by a nine-wicket margin in their last match of World Cup 2015 match played in Sydney on Friday.

image.caption: Chris Jordan bowls
image.longCaption: Chris Jordan bowls, England v Bangladesh, World Cup 2015, Group A, Adelaide, March 9, 2015

videos.subTitle: Afghanistan v England, World Cup 2015, Group A, Sydney
videos.seoTitle: How do Afghanistan rank among WC debutants?

videos.title: Bevan: England will be hurting for a few weeks
videos.subTitle: Afghanistan v England, World Cup 2015, Group A, Sydney
videos.seoTitle: Bevan: 'England will be hurting for quite a few weeks'
videos.summary: Former Australia batsman says England will encounter a tough time as they attempt to come to terms with their poor performance in the World Cup

videos.title: Should England bring back KP?
videos.subTitle: World Cup 2015
videos.summary: As England get ready to pack their bags at the World Cup, Melinda Farrell puts the big question to the fans at the SCG

seriesStandings.notes:
21.10 Progression of Teams 21.10.1 Pool Matches The following point system will apply: Win 2
Tie, No Result or Abandoned 1
Loss 0 In the event of teams finishing on equal points in its Pool, the right to play in the quarter-finals will be decided in the following order of priority:
  • The team with the most wins in the Pool matches will be placed in the higher position.
  • If there are teams with equal points and equal wins in the Pool matches then in such case the team with the higher net run rate in the Pool matches will be placed in the higher position (refer to 21.10.5 below for the calculation of net run rate).
  • If two or more teams are still equal, they will be ordered according to the head to head matches played between them (points then net run rate in those matches).
  • In the highly unlikely event that teams cannot be separated by the above, teams will be ordered according to their original seed-ing.
  • If all matches within a Pool are a no result, the top four seeded teams will progress to the quarter-finals.
21.10.2 Quarter Final If a quarter-final is tied, abandoned or if the match is a no result, then the team that finished in the higher position in the Pool stage shall proceed to the semi-finals. 21.10.3 Semi Final If a semi-final is tied, abandoned or if the match is a no result, then the team that finished in the higher position in the Pool stage shall proceed to the final. 21.10.4 Final In the event of a tied final, the teams shall compete in a Super Over to determine which team is the winner. If following a tie, weather conditions prevent the Super Over from being completed, or if the match is abandoned or a no result, the teams shall be declared joint winners. 21.10.5 Net Run Rate A team's net run rate is calculated by deducting from the average runs per over scored by that team throughout the competition, the average runs per over scored against that team throughout the competition. In the event of a team being all out in less than its full quota of overs, the calculation of its net run rate shall be based on the full quota of overs to which it would have been entitled and not on the number of overs in which the team was dismissed. Only those matches where results are achieved will count for the purpose of net run rate calculations. Where a match is abandoned, but a result is achieved under Duckworth/Lewis, for net run rate purposes Team 1 will be accredited with Team 2's Par Score on abandonment off the same number of overs faced by Team 2. Where a match is concluded but with Duckworth/Lewis having been applied at an earlier point in the match, Team 1 will be accredited with 1 run less than the final Target Score for Team 2 off the total number of overs allocated to Team 2 to reach the target. In circumstances where a match (and the points for such match) is awarded to a team as a result of the other team's refusal to play, either by the umpires in accordance with Law 21.3 (a)(ii) or in accordance with the provisions of the relevant event agreements signed by the participating teams, the net run rate of the defaulting team shall be affected in that the full 50 overs of the defaulting team's innings in such forfeited match shall be taken into account in calculating the average runs per over of the defaulting team over the course of the relevant portion of the competition. For the avoidance of doubt the runs scored and overs bowled in such forfeited match will not be taken into account when calculating the net run rate of the team to whom the match was awarded.

recentReportStory.title: A very English farewell
recentReportStory.subTitle: Afghanistan v England, World Cup 2015, Group A, Sydney
recentReportStory.summary: On a suitably hangdog English day, more downcast than overcast, and a match ravaged by rain, an Ian Bell fifty led England to victory with nine wickets to spare

image.caption: Rain played hide and seek, keeping the ground staff busy
image.longCaption: Rain played hide and seek, keeping the ground staff busy, Afghanistan v England, World Cup 2015, Group A, Sydney, March 13, 2015

recentReportStory.credit: David Hopps is the UK editor of ESPNcricinfo @davidkhopps
